div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div4.p: Harper's Weekly, of 17th January, contains the following advertisement:

q.p: "Confederate (Rebel.) Money.--Fas simile Treasury Notes, exactly like the genuine, $520 in Confederate Notes of the denomination, sent by mail, postage paid, on the receipt of $5.00, by

div4.p:
Harper's Weekly calls itself the "Journal of civilization" --Yankee civilization of course.
In no other country in the world could such an announcement appear in a newspaper.
Such unblushing rascality may well defy the world for a parallel.
A people who glory in the practice and avowal of Penitentiary crimes have been unknown till now in the history of mankind.

div3.head: Transportation on Government account.
div3.p:
The Grand Jury of the G. S. Court at Mobile recently made a presentment on the subject of abuses by Government officers of the transportation facilities placed at their command, from the positions they hold.
In the presentment it was charged that Mr. George B. Clither all, of Mobile, had obtained a permit from Maj. Ashe, Chief of Transportation, for the transportation of "public supplies," and perverted it to the carriage of private goods.
It seems that no permit was given to Mr. C. at all, but that he was acting as a salaried agent for J. E. Powell, of Montgomery, to whom Major A. had given a letter requesting the Quartermaster at New Orleans to permit Powell to ship goods when it did not interfere with the Government shipments.
The following is an extract from a letter of Mr. Powell to Mr. Clitherall explaining the whole communication of the latter with the affair:

"Your services as my agent commenced on the 1st of July, 1862, at a fine salary, previously agreed upon by us; immediately, therefore, on the receipt of the above, (the permit of Major Ashe,) I telegraphed you to come here, and on your arrival placed this letter in your hands.
It was the first knowledge you had of its existence, and you certainly had as little to do with procuring' it as the Grand Jury itself.
You arrived and left here on the same day; our interview was very short, and I remember that I did not explain to you the purposes to which any freight of mine were to be applied, but simply directed you, as my agent, to forward such articles as I might purchase in New Orleans to Mobile, using for that purpose the above letter of Major she, and the power of attorney constituting you my agent"

Mr. Clitherall in a card defending himself from the aspersions made by the presentment of the jury, publishes a letter from the President of the Mississippi railroad, showing that he had never represented himself as a Government agent, nor the shipments as being for the Government, but had expressly disclaimed both assumptions.
During the period that this transportation was going on some of the goods were seized by Government officials, and the entire matter underwent a rigid investigation by the War Department, which resulted in the release of the goods, and the consequent exoneration of the parties from any improper action in the affair whatever.
Having published the presentment of the jury, we publish the above statement as a matter of justice to the gentlemen named in that document.

div4.head: A Winding Sheet for the Union.
div4.p:
Since the Republican caucus at Washington the New York World thinks proofs rapidly thicken that the Radicals intend to close the war in the coming spring.
There is only one more experiment they wish to try, and that is to arm the negroes in the denrely populated slave districts, and send them marauding through the country, stirring up a wide- spread and bloody servile insurrection.
In commenting on an article from the New York Tribune, the World says:

q.p:
They think sixty or ninety days will suffice for this internal experiment; if it falls, they are then ready to abandon the contest and dissolve the Union on the best terms attainable.
This design is clearly shadowed forth in a remarkable article in yesterday's Tribune, from which we will quote enough to substantiate these charges.
The head organ of the Radicals sets out with the postulate that the rebellion can be extinguished in ninety days, if ever. "We believe that it may be virtually crushed out within the next ninety days and that it is far more likely to be within that term than ever afterward. "

div4.p:
The fact that the Radicals are ready to give up if ninety days or less do not finish the business crops out all through the article, as will be seen in the further quotations we will introduce.
The financial basis recommended to sustain these brief operations is stated as follows:

"Borrow temporarily, on the best possible terms, three or four hundred millions, to be paid in at the rate of five millions per day, with a clear understanding that we are to borrow no more — that the war is to be finished with this amount, and that speedily.
It is the never-ending prospect of loans after loans that discourages lenders"

Three hundred millions paid in (and we suppose also paid out) at the rate of five millions a day would last sixty days; four hundred millions, eighty days. The capitalists who furnish this loan are to receive a distinct assurance "that we are to borrow no more — that the war is to be finished with this amount," or, in other words, the Government is to promise to recognize the Confederate States unless it brings them to terms within the brief period required for the expenditure of that sum. In order to spend the money as fast as possible and to make the final blow as vigorous as possible, it is proposed "to call out the uniformed militia of the loyal States for three months, and employ them to garrison Washington, Baltimore, Cincinnati, St. Louis, Louisville, &c., and to hold the line of the Potomac and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, while every soldier now in the service is sent to the front and employed in the active work of the campaign."

All these arrangements are merely ancillary to the main purpose of arming ad the negroes the Government can get hold of, and sending them roving in small bodies through the thickly-settled slave regions, instigating the blacks to rise against their masters, and convert the South into a bloody and flaming Pandemonium.
This purpose is avowed in the following terms:

"Having thus massed our forces and filled our deports and caissons, charge upon the rebels in every quarter — assailing their ports with iron-clads, their armies with stronger armies, fighting resolutely but warily with intent to capture their strongholds and exhaust their resources — while expeditions of light-armed black Unionists, carrying only arms and ammunition, traverse those portions of rebeldom most exposed and thickly peopled with slaves, carrying liberty to all who wish it, and arms wherewith to defend it, moving rapidly and evading all fortified points and overpowering forces, while breaking up railroads and telegraph lines, and making trouble generally."

The Union armies are to be used to concentrate the rebels in defence of their strongholds and important strategic positions, in order that squads of "light-armed black Unionists" may have a free field in roaming over the plantations, and inciting the slaves to insurrection.
We charged when the radicals began to clamor for the proclamation, and to hound on the President to issue it, that this was the object at which they were aiming.
But little more than twenty days have passed since the proclamation, and the truth of the charge is openly confessed.
The intention to bring the war to an immediate close, if the projected servile insurrection does not shatter the strength of the rebellion, is acknowledged with almost equal frankness. "If three months more of earnest fighting," says the Tribune, "shall not serve to make a serious impression on the rebels — if the end of that term shall find us no further advanced than its beginning — if some malignant fate has decreed that the blood and treasure of the nation shall ever be squandered in fruitless efforts--let us bow to our destiny, and make the best attainable peace."

In pursuance of this design to bring the war to a close within the ensuing ninety days, every encouragement is to be given to foreign powers to come forward with proffers of mediation, which, if made, are to be treated "with politeness and most distinguished consideration. " The Radicals wish to have a pacificator at the door if their grand experiment of a gigantic slave insurrection turns out an abortion.
Here is what the Tribune says on this point:

q.p:
"If the great powers of Europe shall see fit to interpose, treat them with politeness and distinguished consideration.
We cannot be required to arrest the war until we shall have substantially agreed on the conditions of peace; we cannot be expected to consider any proposals of mediation until they shall have first been accepted by the rebels.
It will thus be May or thereabout before we can be fairly asked to say yes or no to any such interposition,"

div4.p: In "May or thereabout," that is, at the expiration of the ninety days within which the Radicals wish either to emancipate the slaves or to close the war, they will be glad of a proposition of peace, presented by the foreign powers, to which they "say yes or no." They think this would open and convenient way out of the scrape.

div4.head: An United States view of Affairs in Richmond.
div4.p:
The best history of a modern people, it has been well said, is written in the advertisements of their daily newspapers.
Had such a thing as a file of a Roman gazette come down to us from antiquity.
Bekker's "Galles" would have been an easier book to make and a better book when made.
The New York World has been reading the advertising columns of the Dispatch, and thus comments on their contents:

The stories of reliable refugees and intelligent contrabands do not throw nearly so much light on the real state of things in Jefferson Davis's capital as the business columns of the Richmond papers.
It is hard, for example, to suppose that the Confederate are actually starving when we find Mr. R. Adam advertising for cake bakers, and Mr. Antoni offering to turn out two thousand pounds of candy per day, unless, we suppose, indeed, that they are taking the sage advice of that dauphiness of France who innocently suggested, when the peasantry were dying for lack of bread, that they should be supplied with macaroons.
New Orleans sugar and molasses are put up at auction in spite of Butler and of Banks, and "fine Cuba cigars" are still on hand to soothe the angry Southern mind.
The "State of Virginia" suffers apparently under a surfeit of arms, and her "ordnance department" invites the public to purchase "pistols and guns." Singing birds, which are forbidden by statute to English collegians, must still be heard in the homes of the sacred soil, for canary seed in barrels is advertised by Mr. Robinson.
The luxury of epsom salts is still attainable, notwithstanding the blockade which environs the bowels of the land.
The South still believes that there is "nothing like leather." and an impertinent merchant boldly announces that he has just "run from Baltimore" a quantity of that incomparable material.
The courts of law are busy with patriots who bestow on their brethren the kicks, cuffs, and stabs which a sense of duty to their country ought to make them reserve for the exclusive benefit of the "Hussian invader;" and the Confederate States have such serious cause of grief against one Mr. Wortham that the have ordered their officers to sell his piano, notwithstanding that the instrument is sheltered by the same roof which covers the "Hon. John H. Reagan, Postmaster-General."

As for sofas, bedsteads, carpets, mirrors, cows, hogs, and real estate, they fairly seem to glut the market; and it is painful to observe that in open defiance of the proclamation of January 1, negro men and women are sold and warranted just as coolly as they might be in Kentucky or New Orleans, or any other point in which the "peculiar institution" is protected by the loyalty of its supporters.
People continue to be married and to be buried with exasperating regularity; and young ladies advertise for husbands as audaciously as if the conscription act were a dead letter.
In this connection, it is noticeable that hoop skirts, cambric handkerchiefs, solid headed pins, and embroidered merinos can still be procured for bridal trousseaux. We had supposed Florida to be in the process of colonization by Mr. Eli Thayer, and we are therefore surprised to see that rebellious State still supplying the Confederate conspirators with oranges and lemons.

Two theatres make light of life's realities with new characters, new songs, new dances, and new scenery." Mr. D'Orsey Ogden proposes to "sing all the beautiful music of the part of Bertram in "Guy Mannering;" Miss.
Partington exhibits her agility in a pas seul, and the "Arkansas Comedian" is so little affected by the victories of McClernand that he expects "servants" to pay fifty cents for the pleasure of listening to his most excellent mirth.
Professor St. Maur Bingham, no doubt a member of the noble families of Somerset and Ashburton, flaunts his "fashionable dancing academy" on the verge of the volcano; directors declare dividends on railway stock; family schools are opened for young ladies; and, most wonderful of all, the Confederate States Treasurer begs his fellow-citizens to step up to the Treasury Department and receive the interest on the public debt of the Confederate States"--not payable, we presume, in gold.

On the whole, it is tolerably plain, from a glance over these abstracts and brief chronicles of the time in Richmond that the capture of that city by our forces will be as great a surprise to the inhabitants as to Mr. Stanton or Gen. Halleck.
We wish we could feel perfectly sure that the surprise would not be almost as disagreeable to either of the latter as to the former.

div4.head: The movement in Illinois--startling spread of disaffection to Lincoln's Government — not a dollar to be voted to the war.
div4.p:
The disaffection in the Northwest is most startling in its rapid progress.
The splash of the proclamation in the public mind has extended its waves so far that there is hardly a foot of placid surface on which the Gorilla may sail his crazy wreck in safety.
A few days since the largest Democratic meeting held in Illinois for two years assembled at Springfield in the Capitol of the State.
The Hall of Representatives was crowded to suffocation, and the most enthusiastic applause greeted every expression of the speaker which denounced the President's proclamation, and a war carried on for the purpose of freeing the slaves of the South.

William A. Richardson was the first speaker — He declared his determination to oppose the Executive usurpations of the national administration, and to give no aid to a war carried on to subvert the Constitution by freeing the negroes by a Presidential proclamation.

R. S. Merrick, of Chicago, said that he would suffer death before he would give one dollar or one man to the abolition war carried on under Lincoln's proclamation.
The sentiment was received with tremendous applause.

Judge S. S. Marshall declared that no more citizens of Illinois should be illegally arrested and carried beyond the limits of this State and lodged in a Government has lie. He said that the Democratic party had made up its mind to resist the unlawful usurpations of this imbecile Administration to protect their rights here on the soil of Illinois.

Tom. C. Goudy, of Chicago, spoke with great earnestness and eloquence, taking the ground that the proclamation was a violation of the Federal Constitution and the laws of civilized war; that while the army and navy of the U. States is used to re-establish the authority of the Government, maintain the Constitution, and enforce the laws, it is the duty of all good citizens to sustain the war; but when used to emancipate the negro the war must cease.
As to the remedy for existing grievances the voice of the people has already been heard through the ballot-box, and the Administration should also be warned by the authorities of the States and their Legislatures, as well as public meetings, that further usurpations would not be tolerated; and, after every other expedient had been resorted to, the only remaining right of the people to preserve their liberty and the Constitution as our fathers made it was the right of revolution.
He said there was no danger of anarchy, because the State Governments would be untouched, and a Union could be made upon true republican principles by the States again; but, in order to do this, we must preserve the sovereignty of the States intact.
If the courts are permitted to act, and the habeas corpus writ regarded, this affords a remedy; but when deprived of these, the only remedy is resistance to the usurpation of the Administration.--This war must not be prosecuted to maintain Abraham Lincoln in power or emancipate the slaves, but only to re-establish the Government.
The Committee on Resolutions submitted the following, which was unanimously adopted amid great applause:

Resolved, That the emancipation proclamation of the President of the United States is as unwarranted in military as in civil law — a gigantic usurpation, at once converting the war, professedly commenced by the Administration for the vindication of the authority of the Constitution, into a crusade for the sudden, unconstitutional, and violent emancipation of three millions of negro slaves — a result which would not only be a total subversion of the Federal Union, but a revolution in the social organization of the Southern States, the immediate and remote, the present and far reaching consequences of which, to both races, cannot be contemplated without the most dismal forebodings of horror and dismay.

The proclamation invites a servile insurrection as an element in this emancipation crusade and means of warfare the humanity and diabolism of which are without example in civilized warfare, and which we denounce, and which the civilized world will denounce, as an ineffaceable disgrace to the American name.
Such determined and enthusiastic feeling, says a correspondent, as was exhibited at this meeting has not been exceeded since the war began.
In Huntingdon county, Indiana a large Democratic meeting was held, which passed a series of resolutions, among which are the following:

Resolved, That we regard the restoration of peace to the country, upon honorable adjustment of the issues involved in this calamitous civil war, as paramount to all other considerations; and that in considering the terms of such settlement we will look only to the welfare, peace and safety of the white race, without reference to the effect that settlement may have upon the condition of the African.

Resolved, That it is due to the tax-payers of Indiana that they should know to what purpose their hard earnings have been applied, and that we recommend to the Legislature now about to assemble, the propriety of instituting a strict inquiry, by appropriate committees, into the financial conduct of all our State officers, and more especially that of the Governor, with reference to the prodigal appropriations made by that silly and corrupt Legislature of 1861.

Resolved, That when we survey our present unhappy difficulties as a country, as well as their origin and surroundings, the responsibilities of their authors and the consequences to future generations, the solemn and imposing proportions of the subject inspire with a contempt for everything of a deceitful or time serving character, and impel us to speak frankly and make this solemn declaration: That, had is not been for the fanaticism and peculation of New England, our generation would not have witnessed the ghastly spectre of disunion; and were it not for the same cause, still potent for evil, those difficulties could readily be adjusted.

Therefore, we declare, that when we have exhausted every reasonable effort for the restoration of the Union as it was, should New England stand in the breach, we, as Western man, will consult Western interests find Western pride, which alike forbid, that the great Mississippi Valley should ever be divided, and thereby rendered tributary to a ruinous system of Yankee intolerance, cupidity, and class legislation.
No! never will we for one moment consent to surrender the fellowship of any of her gallant sons, or the rich commerce of her broad acres.
No! The great Mississippi Valley, "now and forever one and inseparable. " Then will we say to New England, with all her cupidity, with all her meanness, fanaticism, follies, and moral turpitude, we bid you good-bye, remembering you only for the wrongs you have done.

list.item:
1.
That next to the liberties of the people and the independence of the States, we most earnestly desire the perpetuation of the Union of the States, but we solemnly proclaim the conviction that this Union can only be preserved by the maintenance of the principles upon which it was founded — the voluntary consent of its members and a scrupulous observance of the rights of each other under the Constitution — and that "war is disunion"

2.
That we have always accorded to others the right to criticize and freely comment upon the acts of public officers, and discuss, in a becoming manner, through the press or otherwise, all subjects in any way concerning us as a people; and we claim the same privilege for ourselves, and will resist to the last extremity any and all attempts, from whatever source they may come, to abridge or interfere with such rights.

3. That tyranny and cowardice are monsters of the same birth, and now, as ever, seek to entrench themselves behind the military and that the keeping up of the army lately, to wickedly and unconstitutionally, and now under the command of Abolitionists and unscrupulous adventurers, is inconsistent with the liberties of the people and already present the frightful proportions of a military despotism.

4. That we have no sympathy with the cause of Secession, and do not believe that in the election of Abraham Lincoln to the Presidency — Abolitionist and co-sectionalist as he was known to be — the Confederate States had any just cause to withdraw from the Union.
But the facts are so apparent that all patriotic, moral, and sensible men, must stand appalled at the unscrupulous perfidy his Administration has inaugurated.
That perjury and usurpation characterize his public career; that neither written Constitution nor official acts affords any guarantee against the licentiousness of his Administration, and that in the wanton and palpable violation of the Constitution of the United States in the suppression of the writ of habeas corpus--in depriving citizens of liberty and property without due course of law — in the levying of war by the President-- in raising an army — in providing and maintaining a navy — in giving a preference in commerce to the ports of one State over another.--in the unreasonable search and seizure of persons and papers — in the desecration of the houses and homes of citizens — in the subjugation of the press in the prostitution of the telegraph-- in the abridgement of the liberty of speech, and like wrongs and usurpations, we have witnessed the overthrow of constitutional liberty in America.

5. That we take pride in rendering a cordial support to our Government in the exercise of all its constitutional functions, without stopping to question their propriety, save at the hustings and ballot-box; our loyalty to our Government shall never be prostituted to sycophantic adulation of a tyrant, or a quiet submission to his usurpations.

6. That we have accepted the Constitution of the United States from our fathers, as a fortress around the liberties of the people prescribing inflexible limits to the powers of the Government in peace as well as in war, and we hold its inviolability paramount to any emergency, and no necessity, however great, can ever justify its violation.

7. That we have unbounded confidence in the gallantry and courage of the Western volunteers, and while disapproving of the war in which they are engaged, with all its ruinous incidents, they have our kindest wishes for their welfare, and safe and speedy return to their homes and friends.

8. That in the President's late message we see nothing to cheer the heart of the patriot, or that promises peace to the country, and we do now declare that we have no confidence in the patriotism of the President or his advisers, and that we unqualifiedly condemn his policy of emancipation of the negro, or the colonization of them among us, with or without compensation.

div4.head: Sinking of the Hatteras.
div4.p: We have received the New Orleans Picayune of the 17th inst., from which we obtain the following particulars of the sinking of the Federal war vessel Hatteras:

div5.p:
On Sunday evening a strange sail appeared off the harbor.
The gunboat Hatteras went in chase about 7 o'clock. A heavy fire was soon after heard, and the sloop-of-war Brooklyn and the gunboat Sciota started in pursuit.
The firing ceased before these vessels reached the spot — some 20 miles from Galveston.

At daylight next day Capt. Lowry, of the Sciota, picked up a boat containing an officer and five men, belonging to the Hatteras.
They reported that at 7 o'clock on Sunday evening the Hatteras ranged up alongside of a steamer which looked like the Alabama; she was hailed by Captain Blake, and replied that "I am her Brittanic Majesty's steamer Spitfire." Capt. Blake said: "Heave to — I will send a boat aboard of you" A boat was lowered — the one spoken of as having been picked up. Just as this boat shoved off the strange steamer opened a furious fire on the Hatteras.

Both vessels then engaged in fierce combat, running ahead of the boat; but soon after — say, about twenty minutes--the officers in the boat saw the Hatteras stop, evidently crippled; then there was loud cheering on board the rebel steamer.
The Brooklyn and Sciota cruised all night, and next morning found the wreck of the Hatteras, sunk in nine fathom water.
Some of her boats were picked up, which contained arms and bloody clothes.
But the victor had disappeared.
The Hatteras was a purchased iron vessel, sister to the steamer St. Mary.
She was unfit for a man-of-war, having no powers of endurance.
Her battery consisted of three small rifled guns, and four short 32 pounders.
The rebels had heavy guns--68 pounders, by the sound.
Opinions differ as to who she was. Some think she was from Mobile, and not the 290.
The rams and fortifications at Galveston are formidable.

div4.head: "my plan."
div4.p: The following is a letter from Lincoln to McClellan about his "plan" for getting to Richmond:

div5.head:
Executive Mansion,
Washington, February 3, 1862.
div5.p:
You and I have distinct and different plans for a movement of the Army of the Potomac--yours to be down the Chesapeake up the Rappahannock to Urbans, and across land to the terminus of the railroad on York river — mine, to move directly to a point on the railroad southwest of Manassas.
If you will give me satisfactory answers to the following questions I shall gladly yield my plan to yours:

list.item:
1.
Does not your plan involve a greatly larger expenditure of time and money than mine.
2. Wherein is a victory more certain by your plan than mine.
3. Wherein is a victory more valuable by your plan than mine.
4. In fact, would it not be less valuable in this, that it would break no great line of the enemy's communication, while mine would.
5. In case of disaster would not a safe retreat be more difficult by your plan than mine.

div4.head: The great Political reaction.
div4.p: In reference to the table of majorities of the elections of 1862, published in the New York Tribune the Cincinnati Courier says:

q.p:
The popular reaction only began in October, after Lincoln's Abolition proclamation was issued, which was September 22d. The Tribune, in order to make out a table for its side, includes Maine and Vermont, which voted in September, and Connecticut, which voted in April, nearly a year ago.--Every one knows that Connecticut would give now from five to eight thousand Democratic majority, and that Vermont and Maine, instead of giving 23,000 Abolition majority, would not, if they had voted after the proclamation, have given half the majority; and Missouri is put down at seven thousand Abolition majority, when there is not a man who doubts if there had been not interference of the military in the election that State would have given 100,000 majority against the Administration.
The Abolition ticket got but 30,000 votes out of the 170,000 there are in the State.
The mistake in Missouri alone would give, by the Tribune's table, if corrected, the Democrats a large majority.
Delaware is put down at 111 for the Administration, although it elected a Democratic member to Congress, and thus condemned the Administration.
On the popular vote of the loyal States there was, last fall, a handsome majority against the Administration.
In electoral votes, had there been a new President chosen, the Tribune's own table makes the account stand thus:

bibl.n: New York Tribune the Cincinnati Courier

div4.head: No Consolation from Abroad.
div4.p: The London correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer writes the following to that paper:

q.p:
There is no doubt that the recent disastrous affair at Fredericksburg, and the Ministerial crisis at Washington, have produced a profound impression upon all classes of the people of England.
As I stated in my last letter, the press generally has seized upon these two occurrences with the greatest avidity, and turned them to as good an account as was in its power.
With the sapient editors of most of the London journals there is no longer any Federal Government, nor a nation known as the United States.
The Southern Confederacy is gradually, but speedily, to swallow up everything on the Western Continent.
Mr. Lincoln is now a President only in name, the Democratic party in New York being virtually the supreme rulers of the fragmentary conglomeration of Northern States.
No language is too gross or indecent with which to express their contempt of Mr. Lincoln and his Cabinet, while the human gentleman, Jeff Davis, is elevated into a demigod.
The utter disruption of the whole country is confidently predicted as likely to occur within a few weeks, and Washington itself into become a common rendezvous for the owls and bats.

bibl.n: The London correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer

div4.head: Mr. Seward's Credit in Europe.
div4.p: A Paris letter, in the New York Tribune, speaking of the Fredericksburg slaughter, says:

q.p:
What bearing that defeat will have on the subterranean negotiations going on between the French and other continental Cabinet's, you can conjecture, and your correspondent can only conjecture.
Its influence on public opinion is most unfavorable to the Union cause.
Southerners and their European advocates naturally make much of this third grand repulse of the attempt to take Richmond by the best appointed and most numerous of Northern armies.
Unionists and their European advocates are depressed, not so much by this more military defeat as by the permanent elements of defeat whose existence and activity it seems to disclose disunion among Unionists, and practicable vigorous unity among disunionists-always the same sound policy of

bibl.n: A Paris letter, in the New York Tribune,

div4.p:
Jefferson Davis leading to a definite purpose per fas et nefas, and still a flabby, flexible policy in what should be the head of our Government, following a dawdling, infirm purpose of perhaps and perhaps not. It is a lamentable truth that no one today of our best friends in Europe feels confident that yesterday was the New Year's day in America of a New Era of Our Lord who called all men brothers.
So little faith in our Government and Northern people's words has been inspired by their work hitherto.

The words of our Government's spokesmen to foreign nations, published in the documents from the Secretary of State's office, are, I am sorry to state, not at all impressive to the European general reader — not more impressive to him than to the various European ministers and diplomats to whom they were originally appointed to be read.
Henry Clay once claimed that he was the best alluded man in America.
Our actual Secretary of State is the best laughed at of all American statesmen in Europe.

div4.head: The London times and the scriptural view of slavery.
div4.p: In an editorial of the London Times, commenting on the share Messrs. Beecher, Chever, Tyng, and others, have taken in this war, the following paragraph occurs:

These gentlemen preach not for an infallible or an established church, for no such church has yet ventured to be as dogmatic and positive on this point as they are. They preach with the Bible in their hands.
In that book there is not one single text that can be perverted to prove slavery unlawful, though there is much which naturally tends to its mitigation, its elevation, and its final extinction.
In the New Testament we have an epistle written by the man who represents the last revealed phase and development of the Gospel, sent by the hand of a runaway slave, who had sought a refuge with the writer, to his lawful master, to the purport that the master and his slave were to get on better and do their duty to one another more thoroughly for the future.
The same writer tells his recent converts that if they are slaves they must make the best of that condition, and not try to escape it, at least by any means contrary to the laws of the country.
The only possible doubt about the exact meaning of his advice is, whether the slaves are to refuse their liberty, even if it be offered, or whether they are merely to remain true to their masters, even if chance presents the opportunity of escape.
The context, which says that a faithful and dutiful Christian slave becomes the freedman of his Heavenly Master, clearly proves that a slave who refuses the offer of freedom has a high scriptural argument for his choice.
If it be said that slavery is at variance with the spirit of the Gospel, so also are a good many things which are not yet laid under the ban of Abolition, or threatened with the "war power." Sumptuous fare, purple and fine linen, wealth, ecclesiastical titles, unmarried clergy, good clerical incomes, and many other things are contrary to the spirit of the Gospel, or, at least, can be proved so as easily as slavery.
But the Roman Catholics have just as much to say for any one of their peculiar doctrines as the Abolitionists have for their one article of a standing or falling community.
Whether the Confederates have done right to throw off the Union is a distinct question, but they cannot have a better defence than a proclamation of war to the knife, a solemn invocation of the "war power" against every slaveowner who still claims the duty of his slave.

This has raised a decided commotion among the Exeter Hall papers of England, and we give the following sample, shaving from the mass.
It is from the Liverpool Post:

The Times has raised a lion in the path of the Southern Confederacy.
For a long period it has supported the Southern cause by every argument ingenuity could suggest, and by every statement an easy and sanguine credulity could adopt.
Southerners, themselves, have been startled by the vehemency of the Times's advocacy and the strength of its assertions.
At length it has gone beyond bounds, and overreached itself. --King Public will suffer his royal ear to be abused a good deal, but there are things to which he will not hearken, and which he must resent.
The Times has actually gone the length of advocating slavery, or at least of asserting that Christianity and the Bible say nothing against it; and this has proved too much for the mental stomach of the English people.
On all sides indignant repudiations are heard.
Nearly the whole press has raised its voice in denunciation of this godless and illiberal doctrine.
Unless we greatly mistake the signs of the times a reaction will set in from this point.
Men will begin to ask themselves what amount of confidence need be placed in a journal which, at its clients's bidding, goes so far as to cast aside British prejudices in favor of freedom, and to justify slavery almost as boldly as Mr. Stephens, the Vice-President of the Southern Confederacy could do.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p: Mrs. Katharine Thomson, the authoress of many works of biography and fiction, died at Dover on the 19th of December. Among the more extensively known of her early productions are: "Constance," "The Life of Raleigh," "Memoirs of the Court of Henry the Eighth," and the "White Mark." Her late works, written conjointly with her son, and published under the noms de plume of Grace and Phillip Wharton, were: "The Queens of Society," and "Wits and Beaux." The "Literature of Society," only just given to the world, was Mrs. Thomson's last work.

A very successful experiment was made recently at Havre with a gun invented by Count Haudetot, for throwing a rope from the shore to a ship in distress.
The rope was carried a distance of 210 yards by a shot weighing ten pounds. The inventor says the greatest distance to which a rope has been thrown by a similar instrument is 200 yards, and that the shot used weighed twenty pounds.

"Fourteen Months in the American Bastiles" is the title of a pamphlet sold by the Appletons and other booksellers, written by Mr. Frank Key Howard, a grand son of the author of our national song, "The Star Spangled Banner."
The New Jersey Legislature has referred the peace resolutions introduced a few days ago to the Committee on Federal Relations.
Lincoln has appointed Mr. Ballet, formerly of N. Orleans, but more recently of Kentucky collector of the port of New Orleans.

div3.head: Confederate States Congress.
div3.p: Senate.--Prayer by the Rev. Mr. Peterkin.

Mr. Yancey, of Ala., introduced a bill to reorganize the Medical Corps of the Confederate States Navy.
Referred to the Committee of Naval Affairs.
Mr. Pholan, of Miss., introduced a bill for the condemnation to the public use of all cotton within the Confederate States, providing for the payment thereof, and for other property.
On motion of Mr. Pholan the bill was referred to a select committee, to be appointed by the President pro tem.

Mr. Semmes, of La., introduced a bill to authorize the Comptroller of the Treasury to obtain the legal advice of the Attorney General.
Referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

Mr. Haynes, of Tenn., submitted a resolution, which was adopted, directing the Committee of the Judiciary to inquire into the expediency of regulating by law the seizure and impressment of private property for public use.

Mr. Brown, of Miss., from the Committee of Naval Affairs, reported back a bill for continuing seamen and ordinary seamen in the service of the Confederate States until the end of the war. The bill was passed.
The bill for organizing a C. S. Supreme Court was again up, but no change was made in it, and it was laid on the table until to-morrow.
The bill to amend the act to organize the clerical force of the Treasury Department was taken up amended, and passed.
The Senate then went into Executive session, and soon after adjourned.
House of Representatives.--The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore.

Mr. Sexton, of Texas, introduced a resolution, which was agreed to, that the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into the expediency and propriety of providing by law, to such an extent as may be within the power of Congress, for the disfranchisement of all such persons — resident citizens of the Confederate States--as may be clearly shown to have refused to aid us in our present struggle for independence, or who may, in any way, have aided or assisted our enemies.

Mr. Gray, of Texas, offered a resolution, that the Judiciary Committee consider the expediency of so amending the sequestration laws as to authorize the Judges of the Courts, in their discretion, to postpone sales of confiscated lands and other property during the war. Agreed to.
Mr. Gray also presented a bill to be entitled an act to amend an act to establish the Judicial Courts of the Confederate States of America, approved March 16, 1861. Referred to the Judiciary.

Also, a bill declaring the legal invalidity of all acts and proceedings affecting the rights of citizens, done under authority of the public enemy, within any State or locality temporarily under their control, or in their possession.
Referred to Judiciary Committee.

Mr. Colilor, of Va., offered a resolution that the Judiciary Committee inquire into the expediency of repealing so much of the law of last session entitled an act to organize Military Courts to attend the army of the Confederate States in the field, and to define the powers of said Courts as invest said Courts with civil jurisdiction " defined as crimes by the laws of the Confederate States, or of the several States; and when beyond the territory of the Confederate States, to all cases of murder, manslaughter, arson rape, robbery and , as defined by the common law, when committed by any private or officer in the army of the Confederate States against any other private or officer in the army, or against the property or person of any citizen or other person not in the army." Agreed to.

Mr. Holcombe, of Va., offered a resolution, which was agreed to, that the Committee of Ways and Means be instructed to inquire into the expediency of embracing money at interest among the subjects of taxation, and of so discriminating as to impose a heavier burden upon creditors who have refused to receive payment of their debts in Confederate Treasury notes.
Mr. Chambiles, of Va., introduced a bill "fixing the time for the election of members to the House of Representatives." The bill is as follows:

The Congress of the Confederate States do enact, That an election shall be held in the several States of this Confederacy on the first Monday in November, 1863, for members of the House of Representatives in the Congress of the Confederate States, which elections shall be conducted in all respects according to the Constitution of the Confederate States and the laws in force for that purpose in the several States.
Referred to the Committee on Elections.

Mr. Boteler, of Virginia, offered a resolution that the Committee on Ordnance be instructed to inquire into the expediency of providing by law for the appointment of a Superintendent of Laboratories.
Agreed to.

Mr. Russell, of Va., offered a resolution that the Committee on the Judiciary inquire into the expediency of requiring debtors against whom judgments or decrees are rendered as garnishees under the sequestration laws to pay or secure the same without delay.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that the same Committee inquire into the expediency of providing, by means of retaliation or otherwise, for the protection of un-armed citizens of the Confederate States from injuries committed by the enemy to enforce a claim of allegiance to the United States or otherwise in violation of the usages of war between independent nations.
Agreed to.

Mr. Staples, of Va., offered a resolution that the Committee on Quartermaster and Commissary Departments inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill authorizing the settlement and payment of claims for property taken or purchased from citizens for the use of the Confederate armies, and for which receipts and vouchers were not given in the manner prescribed by the rules and regulations of the War Department.
Agreed to.

Mr. Lyons, of Va., introduced a bill for the relief of the families of non-commissioned officers and privates of the Confederate army.
Referred to the Military Committee and ordered to be printed.

Also, a bill to provide for funding the currency of the Confederate States.
Referred to the Committee of Ways and Means and ordered to be printed.

Mr. Lyons also offered a resolution that the Committee on the Medical Department inquire into the expediency of allowing to sick and wounded officers hospital accommodations, as well as rations, without charge.
Agreed to.

Mr. Boteler, of Va., introduced a bill to establish a nitre and mining bureau.
Referred to the Committee on Ordnance.

Mr. Goode, of Va., offered a resolution, that the Committee of Ways and Means be instructed to inquire and report whether the claims for arrearages of pay due to deceased soldiers are promptly audited and settled by the 2d Auditor of the Treasury Department; and if not, what are the causes of delay in the settlement and payment of the same; and that said committee also report what legislation, if any, is deemed necessary to secure the prompt and speedy settlement of said claims.
Agreed to

Also, a resolution, that the Committee on Military Affairs inquire into the expediency of providing by law for the detection and punishment of persons habitually engaged as agents in hiring substitutes.
On motion of Mr. Jones, of Tenn., the House went into secret session.

div3.head: General Assembly of Virginia.
div3.p: Senate.--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock by Lieut. Governor Montague, and opened with prayer.
The usual communication from the House, announcing the passage of a number of Senate and House bills, was read by the Clerk.

A communication was received from the Governor, enclosing a letter from M. L. Bonham. Governor of South Carolina, communicating the action of the Legislature of that State relative to the guaranty, by the several States, of the debt of the Confederate Government.
Referred to Committee on Confederate Relations, and ordered to be printed.

A bill was reported increasing the salaries of certain officers of the Government (known as basement officers, Secretary of the Commonwealth, Clerk, Adjutant-General, &c.,) $300 to $500 per year, to continue till 1st January, 1864.

Bills were passed for the relief of Josiah Wynn, or Lee county; for the relief of James M. Laidley, of Kanawha county; and amending the Code so as to allow of the election of but one Major to a regiment.
Bill authorizing the sale of the State's interest in the Hillsboro' and Cincinnati Railroad was laid on the table; also, bill amending certain sections of the fence law.

The bill for the relief of the Clerk of the Hustings Court of Richmond was taken up and advocated by Messrs. Nash and Robertson, and passed.
It provides that the Judge of said Court may make such allowance to the Clerk as he may deem proper in felony cases, not to exceed ten dollars in any one case which may be disposed of; the amount to be paid by the Council of the City of Richmond.

The bill authorizing the Governor, during the war, to appoint as many aids as he may deem proper, only three of whom shall receive pay, (as Lieutenant Colonels of Cavalry,) was ordered to its engrossment.

Resolutions of inquiry into expediency were offered — by Mr. Wiley, of so amending the 8th section of act of Oct. 3d, 1862, as to provide that an agent or overseer shall be employed by the Confederate Government for 20 negroes furnished by those counties of the Commonwealth whose quota does not exceed that number, said agent to be selected by the owners of said slaves; by Mr. Nash, of amending 2d section of 22d chapter of the Code so as to exempt one Deputy Sheriff for every ten thousand inhabitants in each county, and providing for the exemption of one Deputy in every county, whether such county has 10,000 inhabitants or not.
On motion of Mr. Pennybacker, the Senate adjourned.
House of Delegates.--The House met at 12 o'clock M. Prayer by Rev. Mr. Burrows.

A motion was made and carried, adding to the Committee on Privileges and Elections five members.
The Speaker announced the following gentlemen as the addition: Messrs. Magruder, Greene, Robinson of Berkely, McKinney, and Sanders of Franklin.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--By Mr. Fleming, into the expediency of so revising and amending the election laws as to provide for future elections in counties which now are, or may hereafter be, overrun by the public enemy; by Mr. Staples, into the expediency of pasting an act authorizing the County Court of Henry county to sell the district school- houses of said county, and apply the proceeds to the education of poor children.

The Speaker read a communication from Franklin Miner, of Albemarle, resigning his seat as a member of the House, owing to ill health.
On motion of Mr. Magruder, the Speaker was authorized to issue certificate of election to supply the above vacancy.

A communication was received from the Governor, covering a letter from the Governor of South Carolina, conveying an act passed by the Legislature of that State, guaranteeing the Confederate States bonds; also, a second communication from the Governor relative to the militia; both of which, with their accompanying documents, were ordered to be printed.
The bill authorizing the Bank of Rockingham to increase its contingent fund was passed.
The bill authorizing the Exchange Bank of Richmond to declare a dividend was passed.

The Senate resolutions, declaring Lieut. E. S. Gay to be considered commandant of the Public Guard, with all the pay, emoluments, etc., pertaining to the same, from the 13th day of April, 1861, was reported to the House by the committee to whom it was referred.
While it was under consideration.

Mr. Hopkins called for the order of the day, but gave way to have read a resolution from Mr. Worsham, calling upon the Governor to furnish to this House certain information in regard to the troops of the State Line.

The special order of the day — the bill for the suppression of extortion — was at 1 o'clock taken up and put upon its passage.
Considerable time was consumed in its consideration, and various amendments proposed; pending which a motion was made by Mr. Harrison to postpone the whole subject indefinitely.
The motion was finally withdrawn, and the House proceeded to its further consideration until 3 o'clock, when it yielded to the motion of Mr. Ward, and adjourned.

div3.head: Two hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Deserted from Capt. George T. Whittington's company, 19th Va., Battery, stationed at Battery No. 8, Privates Thomas Malone and Thomas Clary. Private Malone is 46 years of age, 5 feet 6 inches in height, fair complexion, dark hair, and blue eyes.
Private Clary is 45 years of age, 5 feet 6 inches in height, light hair, fair complexion, and blue eyes.
The above men were substitutes and besides the above reward, $30 cash will be paid it delivered at Battery No. 8, or either of the Assistant Provost Marshals.

div3.head: Inquest.
div3.p:
--Acting Coroner Richard D. Sanxay yesterday held an inquest over the remains of the two Federal soldiers who were drowned by falling into the James River and Kanawha canal, on the morning of Tuesday, as they were journeying from the Libby Prison to the Petersburg Depot, in this city.
The inquest was held at the headquarters of the City Battalion, on the south side of the Basin.
It was proved by sundry witnesses that the bridge spanning the canal, and whose breaking caused the catastrophe, was fabricated by Moseley & Co., of Cincinnati, Ohio, and had been in use for six years and upwards.
Abundant evidence was on hand that it had been used on all occasions, without fear of the result, up to the late fatal accident.

In addition to the inquiry made by the Coroner into the death of Daniel LaRuke and George Ephart, of company K, 30th Indiana regiment, the two Federal soldiers who lost their lives on the occasion, an effort was made to find out how the "unknown stranger" came to his death.
This latter, as was said on yesterday, resembled a Georgia soldier from his uniform, and had been in the water for several weeks.

The jury, so far as the Federal soldiers were concerned, came to the conclusion that their death was caused by the breaking of the bridge and their subsequent falling into the canal by reason thereof.
As far as the "unknown stranger" was concerned, the jury could not exactly determine, but believed he accidentally fell into the canal and was drowned, and so returned a verdict to that effect.

While the inquest was progressing, another body was fished out of the canal, which proved to be that of F. Padican, of the 18th Mississippi regiment.
It was ordered to be buried without the formality of an inquest.
Three other Federal soldiers yet remain to be accounted

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p:
--Early yesterday morning 21 prisoner; were brought from Lynchburg, by Detective F. A. New, and lodged in Castle Thunder, six of them being honed.
They were charged with various offences.
On the same day were lodged in the Castle for desertion: Thomas Hunt, co F, 40th Va reg't; Thomas Wilkinson, co. F, 53d Va; both sent from Halifax county. Five conscripts sent from Henrico county by Lieut. Haines; Wm. Fussell, soldier, deserter from hospital at Howard's Grove; Ro Clarks, John Higgins and Geo Appleby, all three deserters from co K, 15th La; James E. Longhrids, Richmond Light Artillery; Wm. Clarke, 46th Va. battalion; Horace Transom, co E, 53d N. C; Jas Brown.
co D, 19th N. C. There were yesterday over 500 persons confined in this prison.

div3.head: Fire.
div3.p:
--The alarm of fire raised on Tuesday night, about 9 o'clock, was caused by the ignition of the wood work in the second story of the building occupied as a dry goods store by G & M Rosenbaum, on Broad, between 4th and 5th streets.--Rosenbaum's store was considerably damaged; but, by dint of great exertion on the part of the firemen, the flames were extinguished before the house was destroyed or the property adjoining materially injured.
The upper part of Rosenbaum's dry goods store was occupied by tenants, who suffered some inconvenience by the removal of their furniture and the damage consequent on a plentiful it flux of water.
The fire was accidental.

div3.head: The Results of extortion and Speculation.
div3.p: --The state of affairs brought about by the speculating and extortion practiced upon the public cannot be better illustrated than by the following grocery bill for one week for a small family, in which the prices before the war and those of the present are compared:
So much we owe the speculators, who have staid at home to prey upon the necessities of their fellow citizens.

div3.head: The Abolition Prisoners.
div3.p:
--Fight hundred Abolition soldiers remain in the military prison of this city.
They will be sent off on Saturday next the Yankee steamboat captain having promised to call for them at that time at City Point.

div3.head: Arrest.
div3.p:
--The only arrest accomplished by the civil police yesterday was that of George Quarles, taken in custody for stealing a ping of tobacco from George W. Gretter.
He will be brought before the Mayor this morning.

div3.head: Court proceedings.
div3.p: --Alexander Zollman arrested on suspicion of being the proprietor of a Faro bank, was acquitted of that offence, and required to give security in $500 for his good behavior for twelve months--which he did.
Mary Cousins, a free negro, in the city with Henrico papers, was ordered a licking for staying here contrary to law.

George W. Price was brought up, on the complaint of Anna Thompson, of 12th and Cary sts., who charged the defendant with assault and battery, repeated efforts to take her life, and destroying her furniture generally and her wardrobe of wearing apparel particularly.
The Mayor acquitted the accused after hearing the evidence.
Samuel, slave of C. H. Chalk, was ordered 25 lashes for stealing a cloak worth $6 and a bunch of keys, from E. M. Shains.

C. S. District Court.--The time of this Court yesterday was occupied in the trial of Chas. A. Pittman, a soldier, charged with forgery.
The testimony made it appear that Pittman purchased a check on the Treasury for $126 from an unknown party, and that when it was presented it called for $1,025. The question left for the jury to determine was whether he did or did not alter the check.
A number of witnesses were examined.--Mr. Daniel Ratcliffe appeared for the accused, and Mr. P. H. Aylett for the Confederate States.
After hearing all the evidence, the jury came to the conclusion that the defendant was not guilty, and any quitted him.

Hustings Court.--The case of Theodore Whitman, arrested by the military authority for selling liquor without a license, and on habeas corpus before Judge Wm. H. Lyons, of the Hustings Court, to try whether the arrest was legal or not, was again heard yesterday before Judge Lyons--Mr. Culd arguing the case for the Government, and Mr. W. W. Crump for the petitioner.
The decision was reserved.

Specie And Bank Notes.--The demand for gold continues moderately active, and the brokers are now asking $2.20 premium; for small amounts, $2.25. The rates for silver are $1.90@2.00--firm.
Bank currency is also tending to higher rates.
For Virginia and North Carolina the brokers are asking 35 et, and for Georgia and South Carolina 40 per cent. The buying rates are about five cents below these figures.

Bonds and Stocks.--The prices of Bonds and Stocks remain at about our last quotations, viz: Confederate States Bonds, $100 and int; Virginia 6's, reg'd at 1.30, North Carolina do, 1.30, do 8's, 1.16 and int; Missouri 6's, 1.22, South-Side R R guaranteed Bonds, 1.15; City of Petersburg do, 1.25; Exchange Bank Stock, 1.06; Farmers' Bank, 1.05; Bank of the Commonwealth, 1.05; Bank of Va., 73; Va Central E. R. Stock, 75.
Exchange.--We quote exchange on London at $2.20, firm, with sales at these figures.

Wheat.--Prime qualities of Red and White, $3.40@3.50.
Transactions mostly on Government account.

Corn.--Very little in market.
We quote it firm at $3.75.
Flour.--Superfine, $20, Extra, $22 to $23; and Family, $24 to $23.
Corn Meal.--Scarce and in demand at $4 bushel, with an advancing tendency.

Tobacco.--The market continues animated and prices firm.
We note recent sales as follows: Lugs, $9.50 to 15; Common Leaf; $12 to 20; Fine Manufacturing, $30 to 45.
Breaks and receipts very light.

Groceries.--Sugar — Brown 92½ to 28, (prime;) White Clarified, $1.10. Molasses, $11 gallon.
Coffee, $4@1.25 --retailing at $5. Tea — retail price, $16 10; Salt, 30 Rice, 10@12½c.

Provisions.--Bacon — hoground, ½75@30c in demand.
Butter, $1.25@1.50.
Cheese, $1.@1.50 Lard, 25 @31, and in demand.
Eggs, 90 etc.@31 dozen.
Irish Potatoes, $4 per bushel; Sweet, very scarce and high.
Onions, $44@30 bbl. Beans.
$5@6 bushel.
Peas, 3½4 bushel.

Fruit.--Apples scarce and in less demand.
We quote at $35 @40 bbl. Pippins, 40@45 bbl. Dried Apples, $5@6.
Dried Peaches, $10@12 bushel.
Seeds.--Timothy, $7; Clover, $27@30 bush., and dull.
Liquoils.--Whiskey, $25@27.52, Apple Brandy, $12.50; French Brandy, $50 gallon.

div3.head: Late from Nassau.
div3.p: --One day's later advices from Nassau report the selling of a number of steamers for Southern ports.

A dispatch just received from Harderville says that Capt. Earie's artillery attached a Yankee gunboat at Buckingham Ferry, on Tuesday.
The Confederates sustained no loss.
The enemy's loss is unknown.

div3.head: Running the blockade.
div3.p: --Another steamer, with a valuable cargo, has arrived in a Confederate port, and two others have safely departed.

div3.head: Another steamer arrived.
div3.p: --Still another English merchant steamer ran into a Confederate port this morning, with a general cargo of merchandise.--She left Nassau on the 25th inst., This is her first trip to the Confederate coast.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 25, page 2.

div3.head: Senator Wall.
div3.p:
This gentleman, the newly-elected Senator from New Jersey, has made a very bold speech in Philadelphia, some account of which we published yesterday.
Mr. Wall was a victim of the Lincoln despotism, and was imprisoned in Fort Lafayette for come months.
His people expressed their contempt for his persecutors and their regard for him by electing him to the United States Senate.

Mr. Wall declares boldly for peace, and for "the great principles which are embodied in the amendments to the Constitution of the United States," "every one of which, " he adds, "has been trampled under foot by the present Administration."

It is plain that a great revolution has been wrought in the Northern public mind.
It is a striking example of the fact that this prominent gentleman who has been, upon suspicion, made to suffer the horrors of Federal imprisonment, has been chosen a member of the Senate and is now permitted boldly to impeach the Administration of the greatest usurpations and outrages.
That he is not again sent to the Bastile is not owing to the forbearance of Lincoln, but to his fear.
He knows the people of the North will not sustain him in a repetition of his tyrannous and unjust imprisonment of prominent Northern men, without accusation and without trial.
Wall goes to Congress to reflect the opinions of his people against the acts of the usurper and in favor of peace.
He will no doubt prove an able and gallant compeer of those other brave and patriotic men who have already opened the war upon the Administration with such force and effect.
They will be joined by the newly-elected members of the next Congress when that shall meet, and will then have the numerical force as well as the moral courage and talents to control the measures of that body.

In regarding this account of Mr. Wall's career and conduct and his vindication by his people along with the many remarkable indications of the great revolution in public sentiment, let us remember that to the heroism and constancy of the people of the South alone are they to be attributed.--Had the furious sentiment of Northern radicalism and the brutal tyranny of Lincoln and his Cabinet been sustained by great victories — had there been little or no stop to their armies for subjugation and the South had proved unable to oppose them — why, in such case there had been no revolution at the North.
Lincoln would have been sustained.
New England would have been in the ascendant and none would have dared to raise a voice against him or to hint a doubt of the integrity or virtue of the Puritan race.
The severe blows dealt by the brave South struck out the sparks which have it. lumined the dark Northern sky. Our achievements in the battle-field gave the Northern press and tongue, which had been dumb, a voice; and to-morrow if we fail, that press and tongue would be again dumb that Northern sky again enshrouded in darkness.
So that, whatever encouragement we find in the recent signs from the North, we must know that since they are wrought by ourselves we alone can increase and strengthen them.
Our unanimity and enthusiasm in defence of our rights spread- discord in the ranks of the enemy, and our brave army will move the wedge that will split the Northern Union in twain and bring isolation and ruin upon that portion of that "peculiar people" which has fomented all the strife, all the evils that have fallen upon the two lands.

div3.head: Boarding.
div3.p:
The fact that the Harriet Lane was carried by boarding is significant.
The account of the battle states, that after pouring a destructive volley among her crow from double barrel shot guns (an other proof of the value off that inestimable weapon) the Confederate boarded her, and completed their victory.
This operation is one of the severest tests of the valor of seamen.
To get upon an enemy's decks, and whip him on his own dunghill in a hand-to-hand fight, is universally regarded as the best proof of superior pluck which seamen can give.
The British used to say, in the last war, that the Yankees fought very well at long law, but that they rarely ventured to board a vessel.
John Bull always prided himself upon his backbone at close quarters, and the Confederates seem to be his genuine kinsmen in this respect.
We have got the men to make us great in naval warfare, if we only had the ships.

Boarding, at the present time, is a trying operation, at land as well as sea. If any one doubts it they would better try some of the high-price boarding houses.
In comparison with the successful accomplishment of that achievement, boarding the Harriet Lane in a very small affair.

div3.head: Gen. Fitz John Porter.
div3.p:
The Yankee papers announce that Gen. Fitz John Porter has been "dishonorably dismissed" the Yankee service.
We had always understood that Gen. Porter was one of their best officers, and are inclined to think from the fact that he has violated Yankee ideas of "honor," that he must be a gentleman.
Perhaps they mean by the expression "dishonorably dismissed," that the dismissal was dishonorable, rather than the man, and in that point of view they may have blundered on the truth.
We tender Gen. Porter our sympathies in his afflections, and would suggest to him and others like him, not to put their honor in Yankee keeping, if they want to come off unscathed.

div3.head: The mountain passes.
div3.p:
Gen. Floyd's advice to protect Southwestern Virginia by defending the mountain passes is the obvious dictate of common sense, and should be immediately acted upon.
A handful of undisciplined troops can easily make each of there passes a Thermopylæ. We hope no time will be lost in adopting this obvious means of rendering impregnable one of the most valuable and vital sections of the whole Southern Confederacy.

div3.head: Put them in the army.
div3.p:
Our Generals can do no better service at present than seizing all the extortioners who are selling articles at such enormous prices to the soldiers and putting them in the army.
Fellows who can make such famous charges should have bayonets put in their hands at once, and try their charging qualities upon the enemy.

div3.head: Contributions to Fredericksburg relief Fund, received by R. R. Howison, Treasurer.
div3.p:
--Olivet Church, King and Queen county, $30; Ashland Baptist Church and congregation, $5; Richmond L I Blues, (46th Va.) through Lieut. E. J. Levy, 163.75; Mrs. S. S. Winston, Hanover 10;, Mrs. A. C. Darracott, 10, Miss. Eliza Chiles, 5; Dr. Thomas Pollard, 10; Geo. W. Mordecal, Raleigh N. C., 100, Wood Bondin, Charlotte, 30; W. E. Coleman and family, Amherst, 22; Oakland Church, Goochland, 65.80; A. M. Pomdexter, Halifax, 10; Anonymous, 10; a lady of Louisa 50; officers end men at Drewry's Bluff, through Capt. S. S. Lee, C. S. N. 747; Warsaw Church, Westmoreland, 54.25; Carmel church, Westmoreland, 24.59; St. James Church, Mecklenburg, 116.50; citizens of Augusta, through John Hamliton, 204; Rev. div4.p:
On the 27th inst., Mrs. PrœSe.
Fergusson, wife of Wm. J. Fergusson, aged 35 years.

Her funeral will take place from her husband's residence, corner of 3d and Charity streets, at 10 o'clock this morning.
The friends and relatives of the family are invited to attend. *
On the 27th inst., at 10 o'clock, of inflammation on the brain, Sarah Elizabeth, youngest child of Dandridge H. and Bettle M. Minson, aged 3 months and 14 days.
The Lord giveth and the Lord hath taken another tie from its heart-stricken parents.
On the 27th instant, Lieut. John Reilley, of co. B, 5th La. Vols.
His funeral will take place at 11 o'clock to-day, from his residence, on Wall street, between Main and Franklin.
On the 27th instant, at 9 o'clock P. M., Linda Lee, fifth daughter of Martha A. and James R. Chiles.

The funeral will take place from the residence of her parents, on 9th street, French Garden Hill this (Thursday) afternoon at 3 o'clock. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend. *

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, at her home in Halifax county, Va., Jan'y 17, 1863, Mrs. Mary E, wife of A. H. Richardson, Esq., aged 35 years.

No eulogy it needed or intended here, but the eyes of distant friends may trace this humble tribute of a living heart to the virtues of the beloved deceased.
Owing to delicate health her position in life was a retired one; but beautifully, and with astonishing perseverance, did she fulfill the duties of a Christian wife, mother, friend, and mistress.

From the days of her girlhood she was a communicant of the Church, whose heavenly ways she truly prized.
Her end was peace, perfect peace, in Jesus, and now--

lg.l: "She shines in the light of God,

div4.p: May the bereaved husband and child, and all who loved her, follow her as she followed Christ. *

div4.head: Tribute of respect.
div4.p: At a meeting of the officers on duty at Camp Lee convened on the 27th day of January, for the purpose of paying a tribute of respect to the memory of the late Lieut. John F. S. Beard, of Augusta county the following preamble and resolutions were adopted:
Whereas, it hath pleased Almighty God to remove from our midst our fellow officer, the late Lieut. Jno F. S. Beard: Therefore,

list.item: Resolved, 1 That while we how in humble submission to the decrees of that God who is "too wise to err," we yet deplore the untimely death of our deceased comrade, and bear in affectionate remembrance the many virtues that adorned his life, and that had endeared him to us and all who knew him.

2.
That in his death we have lost a generous, brave, and amiable companion, and the Government the services of an officer conscientious and faithful to its interest, who evinced his devotion to his country's cause by eagerly responding to the first' call to arms, even before he had attained that age which subjects to military duty.
3. That we who have associated with him and know him best testify to his moral worth, and sympathize deeply with his bereaved family in their irreparable loss.
4. That a copy of the above be transmitted to the family of the deceased, and, also, that the proceedings be published in the Richmond and Staunton papers.

div4.closer:
Jonathan Talley, Chairman,
Capt. Goochland Lg't Ar'ty.
Jas. F. Grattan, Sec'y.
Staunton papers please copy. *

div3.head: Twenty-five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on the night of the 24th instant, a mulatto man named Willis.
He is stout and well made; of good height; thin beard; between 30 and 36 years of age; quick in his movements, but scarcely ever speaking unless spoken to, and had on when he went away a drab sack coat, drab pantaloons, and a dark drab hat. He is well acquainted on James river, from Lynchburg to Richmond, and especially on that part touching Albemarle and Buckingham.
He may attempt to pass himself off as a free man, and hire himself to some officer with a view to getting to the enemy, or he may be lurking in the neighborhood of his wife, who belongs to Mr. N. Y. Cabell, of Nelson co. I will pay the above reward if he is lodged in any jail so I can get him again.

closer.signed: W. C. Scott, Powhatan C. H.

div3.head: Runaway.--$25 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran off from the subscriber, in the city of Richmond, on the 27th inst., a black Girl, about 14 years old, not very good teeth in front.
She was purchased of Mrs. Mary W. Coleman, of Caroline county, and may be making her way back.
I will pay $25 for her arrest and delivery to Hill, Dickinson & Co.

div3.head:
Camp 3d Virginia Infantry,
near Fredericksburg, Va.,
January 23d, 1863.
div3.p:
the following named members of Co. H, 3d Va. Infantry, are hereby notified to report to their Company, or send a Surgeon's certificate, properly endorsed, within five days after the publication of this notice: Oscrola Barham, George W. Gleason, George Barrett, Thomas Gostin, Wm. E. Wert, H. B. Gay, and James P. Lash.
If you fail to comply promptly with this notice.
I shall treat you as deserters, and offer the usual reward of $30 for your delivery.

div3.head:

January 28th 1862.
four hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:

Ro Hughes is about 6 feet high, dark skin, and about 25 years old; Richard Nelson, 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, mulatto, and about 22 years old; Frank, 5 feet 8 inches high, dark skin, and about 25 years old. Frank was formerly on the York River railroad.
Elijah Campbell, 5 feet 10 inches high, dark skin, and about 23 years old. The above reward will be paid for the delivery of the four, or $100 for the delivery of either one, at the City Gas Works, Rocketts.
